bibl.title: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, July 17, 1890

div1.p: Lazear has finished at the University of Edinburgh, where he receives recognition for his good work. He visits Glasgow and describes a trip through the Lake Country.

div1.head: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, July 17, 1890
div1.p:
Your letter of July 7
reached me this morning. Those sudden
changes of temperature that we have
in America are very trying. I am
glad however that you got over
your attack of cholera morbus so soon.
Of course that was something it was
impossible to guard against.

I have all my things packed up.
Tomorrow morning Norris, Knapp and I start
for the Lakes. We reach a town at the
foot of Ben Lomond in the afternoon
and we will stop there over night and
climb the mountain. We get to Glasgow
on Saturday. The rest of the party will
stay in Glasgow a day and then go
to the Highlands for a week. I will
return to Edinburgh and take a steam-
boat excursion on Sunday to Dundee
going by way of the Forth, the North Sea
and the Fay. On Monday I will
go on to London. I leave l my baggage
here while I am off on the lake trip
I have entirely finished up at the
University. I said good-bye to all
to-day, and received the prize which
consisted in a medal. I also got
an honourary certificate in the
senior course.

I spent a delightful day yesterday
on the lakes which I will try
to tell you about later
We stopped over night at Lowardennan
at the foot of LockBen Lomond, P
We intended to climb the mountain
last night but a cloud settled
over it and we know that we
could not see the view. So we
took a row on the Loch Lomond
This morning we got up at five
o'clock and climbed the mountain
It was clear when we started
but before we reached the top,
a cloud covered it, so we could
not get the view from the top.

However we got some magnificent
views from the lower levels. We descended
the mountain and took the boat for the
foot of Loch Lomond at 9.25

I will not attempt to describe the
scenery, but will simply say where
we went. We went by rail
through Dumfernline &, Sterling to Aberfoyle
then by coach to the Trosachs and
on to Loch Katrine by boat on
Loch Katrine and by coach across
to Loch Lomond and down
Lock Lomond by steamer.

The scenery is magnificent and
entirely beyond my powers of description,
but it has already been described
by a master hand, Scott in “Lady of
the Lake”.

I will write you a longer letter when
I get to London
